body: Yes that totally normal, since the copy request is issued on the destination remote, it also uses the user of it. So when you are copying to a drive where the destination user doesn't have access to the source it returns a 404. Also when using normal to teamdrive or reverse it needs the patch from #3097 . I already thought about making an additional check that when using serverside over different remotes that it automatically disables serverside when it gets that error.

So in order to benefit from the server side copies on a non-team drive, what does the user have to actually do?  Share the folder with the destination?  If that is the case, this really isn't any different than simply clicking the 'add to my drive'  after the sharing and syncing using the existing remote:

rclone sync remote1:sharedfolder remote1:destfolder

Am I correct?  If so, this really needs to be a OPT IN, rather than a OPT OUT feature.  Most people won't have shared a folder with a different account when syncing between remotes.
For normal drive the destination need to be shared with, yes, either as everyone or direct share. But 'add to my drive' doesn't create a copy, but instead links it.

Yes I know it doesn't actually copy it. But when you link to it, you can essentially do what this is doing by copying from the same remote for source to destination.

Since most people will not have "shared" the directory be default, do we think this should be "opt in" rather?

If i'm reading this correctly, won't that mean that **for each and every file** that is part of a copy/move operation that it'll fail first with a 404 and then switch to a regular copy?  My concern is that the majority of users do not 'share' the folder between remotes which seems to be required to enable this to work so the majority of users by default will face many 404s and more API hits and slower operations because of the failure test.

Is my concern not correct?
yes it first tries to use serverside copy and then switch. The normal user mostly doesn't copy between multiple users, so this case wont happen that often
I tend to disagree. In the case of non-teamdrive users most users who copy between remotes and between gdrive remotes and by that very nature they are using two different users.
I could disable serverside for the whole session if it doesn't have access to the other remote.
That sounds like a good option to me. If it's possible to determine the access doesn't exist and to disable for the session, I think that would be good rather than for each file.

issue.title: Fix move and copy from TeamDrive to GDrive

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?
When trying to copy or move between a TeamDrive and normal GDrive the SupportsTeamDrive flag will not be set since the destination isnt aware of the Source

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?
Nope
#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body: @fionera could we get this PRed now that the other one got merged ?
Yes but it has to be tested. I currently cannot test it...
If the user has full drive access to both remotes, could rclone not issue API commands to properly set the permissions on the source?
technically yes but this can be introduce a lot of complexity and errors
I tested the proposed patch under my scenario and it still seems to attempt a server-side copy for each file resulting in 404s before each and every copy.

> 
> 
> technically yes but this can be introduce a lot of complexity and errors

fair enough, I can completely understand that. Thanks for answering.

@fionera Is there another patch I can test?  or can we convert this to 'opt-in' rather than 'opt-out'?    

My personal feeling is this really should be 'opt-in' as server side copies have far more stringent quotas than regular copies.  But that is better answered by @ncw  I think as whether it should be a opt-in or opt-out.
